<html><body><div><div data-test-id="text" class="arrow-component arr--text-element text-m_textElement__e3QEt text-m_dark__1TC18 "><p>Eritrea on Monday denounced accusations by <em><strong>Ethiopia</strong></em> that Eritrean troops were present inside the country as "false and fabricated".</p><p>Relations between the two Horn of Africa countries have long been fraught but in recent months, Addis Ababa has accused Eritrea of supporting insurgents on Ethiopian soil -- allegations Asmara denies.</p><p>On Saturday, <em><strong>Ethiopia</strong></em> demanded that Eritrea "withdraw its troops from Ethiopian territory". </p><p>"The patently false and fabricated accusations against Eritrea... is astounding in its tone and substance, underlying motivation and overarching objective," said Eritrean Information Minister Yemane Gebremeskel in a statement.</p><p>"Sadly, it constitutes yet another deplorable act in a pattern and spiral of hostile campaigns against Eritrea for more than two years now," he said.</p><p>He added that Eritrea had "no appetite for, or desire to, engage in meaningless acrimony to add fuel and exacerbate the situation".</p><p>Addis Ababa also accused Asmara of collaborating with rebel groups fighting federal forces, particularly in the Amhara region, labelling them not "just provocations but acts of outright aggression".</p><p>Eritrea, one of the world's most closed countries, gained independence in 1993 after decades of armed struggle against <em><strong>Ethiopia</strong></em>. </p><p>They later fought a 1998-2000 border war in which tens of thousands died.</p><p>Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed initially sought rapprochement with Eritrea when he came to power, earning him the Nobel Peace Prize in 2019.</p><p>The two governments cooperated against rebels from <em><strong>Ethiopia</strong></em>'s Tigray region during the 2020-2022 conflict but fell out over the peace accord, from which Eritrea was excluded, and which stipulated the withdrawal of foreign soldiers.</p><p>The Tigray civil war killed at least 600,000 people, according to the African Union, and the resulting peace deal, known as the Pretoria Agreement, has never fully resolved the tensions.</p><p>Eritrean soldiers have been present in the Tigray region since the war, but after the end of hostilities they have increasingly been at loggerheads.</p><p>Eritrea accuses landlocked <em><strong>Ethiopia</strong></em> of coveting its Assab port, with Abiy insisting for years his country must have access to the sea through peaceful means.</p> </div></div></body></html>
